pullRequest.title: Parser for Linkage Checker exclusion file

nodes.bodyText: This part does not work with Windows.
Optional, and maybe not in this PR: writing an XSD, RELAX NG schema, or DTD can be an effective way to document this and si sometimes helpful in runtime validation.
Outer classes are easier to follow and reason about.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,177 @@ +/* + * Copyright 2020 Google LLC. + * + * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); + * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. + * You may obtain a copy of the License at + * + * http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 + * + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software + * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and + * limitations under the License. + */ + +package com.google.cloud.tools.opensource.classpath; + +import com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList; +import java.io.FileInputStream; +import java.io.IOException; +import java.nio.file.Path; +import java.util.ArrayDeque; +import org.xml.sax.Attributes; +import org.xml.sax.InputSource; +import org.xml.sax.SAXException; +import org.xml.sax.XMLReader; +import org.xml.sax.helpers.DefaultHandler; +import org.xml.sax.helpers.XMLReaderFactory; + +/** + * Parser for Linkage Checker exclusion files. + * + *

The exclusion file for Linkage Checker is an XML file. Its top-level element is + * LinkageCheckerFilter. The XML file contains the following structure: + * + *

    + *
  • A LinkageCheckerFilter element has zero or more LinkageError elements. + *
  • A LinkageError element has at least one of Target element and Source element. + *
  • A Target element has Package, Class, Method, and Field elements. A Source element has + * Artifact, Package, and Class elements. + *
  • Method and Field elements have “className” attribute. + *
+ * + *

Each type of the element works as a corresponding matcher, such as LinkageErrorMatcher for a + * LinkageError element and SourceMatcher for Source element. Given a linkage error, they work as + * below: + * + *

    + *
  • A LinkageErrorMatcher matches when all of its child elements match the linkage error. + *
  • A SourceMatcher matches a linkage error when the source class of the error matches one of + * its child elements. + *
  • A TargetMatcher matches a linkage error when the target symbol (class, method, or field) of + * the error matches one of its child elements. + *
  • A PackageMatcher matches the classes that have Java package specified by its name field. + * Prefix to specify child packages. + *
  • A ClassMatcher matches the class specified by its name attribute. ArtifactMatcher, + * PackageMatcher, and ClassMatcher also match methods and fields on their matching classes. + *
  • A MethodMatcher matches method symbol specified by className and name attribute. + *
  • A FieldMatcher matches field symbol specified by className and name attribute. + *
+ */ +class ExclusionFileParser { + + static ImmutableList parse(Path exclusionFile) + throws SAXException, IOException { + + XMLReader xmlReader = XMLReaderFactory.createXMLReader(); + LinkageErrorMatcherHandler handler = new LinkageErrorMatcherHandler(); + xmlReader.setContentHandler(handler); + + InputSource inputSource = new InputSource(new FileInputStream(exclusionFile.toFile())); + xmlReader.parse(inputSource); + return handler.getMatchers(); + } + + private static class LinkageErrorMatcherHandler extends DefaultHandler {

nodes.bodyText: you can check that the namespace is empty before the switch statement and error or ignore if it isn't
watch for namespaces
Does startsWith work here or do we need a period or forward slash at the end to avoid accidental matches?

For example, {@code PackageMatcher("com.google")} matches {@code com.google.Foo} class as well + * as {@code com.google.cloud.Bar}. + */ +class PackageMatcher implements SymbolProblemTargetMatcher, SymbolProblemSourceMatcher { + + private final String packageName; + + PackageMatcher(String packageName) { + this.packageName = checkNotNull(packageName); + } + + @Override + public boolean match(Symbol problem) { + return problem.getClassBinaryName().startsWith(packageName);

nodes.bodyText: can target come after source too?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,25 @@
+<LinkageCheckerFilter>
+  <LinkageError>
+    <Source>
+      <Class name="reactor.core.publisher.Traces" />
+    </Source>
+  </LinkageError>
+  <LinkageError>
+    <Target>
+      <Package name="jdk.vm.ci" />
+    </Target>
+    <Source>
+      <Package name="com.oracle.svm" />
+      <Package name="com.oracle.graal" />
+      <Package name="org.graalvm" />
+    </Source>
+  </LinkageError>
+  <LinkageError>
+    <Target>

nodes.bodyText: There's a combinatorial explosion here: every source class against every target method/field. Perhaps each target should have at most one source and at most one target and each target can have exactly one child.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,12 @@
+<LinkageCheckerFilter>
+  <LinkageError>
+    <Target>
+      <Method className="com.google.Foo" name="methodA" />

nodes.bodyText: does this include subclasses?

commit.message: Error if namespace is not empty

nodes.bodyText: Nice idea. Created #1277
Moved this to an independent class.

nodes.bodyText: Added that check to throw an error if namespaceURI is not empty.
Added that check.
Updated the logic. "com.ab" should not match "com.abcd" here. Added test testParse_targetPackage_unmatch.

nodes.bodyText:
It is unclear what this stack does or how it works. Some comments would be helpful.
It might be that stack is not the best data structure here. A custom class might work better.

It looks like the fields are half reusable and half not. Do you intend a single handler to be used to parse more than one document or not? Either way and make sure to document this and either:
Throw an IllegalStateException the second time startDocument is called
or
reset all fields in startDocument
This is not really followup eligible. We need to get this right in the design now, not fix it later.
nodes.diffHunk:

+  <LinkageError>
+    <Target>
+      <Method className="com.google.Foo" name="methodA" />

commit.message: Target and Source to have only one child

nodes.bodyText: Added IllegalStateException and Javadoc.
Added javadoc to the stack. (Let me know if you think a custom class can express this better than stack.)
More validation in XML structure is to be done at #1277
Is the order of the matchers significant?

An instance of this class can process one document and cannot be reused for other documents. + */ +class ExclusionFileHandler extends DefaultHandler { + + /** + * Stack to hold the ancestors of the XML element in {@link #startElement(String, String, String, + * Attributes)}. + */ + private ArrayDeque stack = new ArrayDeque<>(); + + private ImmutableList.Builder matchers; + + ImmutableList getMatchers() {

nodes.bodyText: Why is the argument type Object? It seems this could be more specific.
Suggest changing message to "unrecognized element: " + qName + " in namespace " + namespaceURI

namespaceUri
qualifiedName
I'd suggest that as documentation, not as part of the processing chain.
It's OK and arguably better to simply ignore unrecongized elements.
final

nodes.bodyText: Good catch. It's SymbolProblemTargetMatcher interface. Updated.
Fixed.
Nice. Updated.
Started writing https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/cloud-opensource-java/wiki/Linkage-Checker-Exclusion-File

I prefer to show errors for unrecognized elements. The errors help to detect typos.
More validation will be done in #1277
Updated.

nodes.bodyText:
This is an awful lot of casting and instanceof, and it makes me wonder if we're not taking advantage of polymorphism where we could, or perhaps we don't have quite the right class hierarchy.
Is there perhaps some way SymbolProblemMatcher.setMatcher could simply work when it's passed any instance of SymbolProblemTargetMatcher?
I don't think this case can happen, given that this case would have been detected already unless the document is malformed, in which case you'll also have errored out before this is called.
I'm not sure this case is reachable either
!stack.isEmpty()

SymbolProblemMatcher.setMatcher could simply work when it's passed any instance of SymbolProblemTargetMatcher?

No, SourceMatcher cannot take FieldMatcher. I replaced the stack and this function with the two variables linkageErrorMatcher and symbolProblemMatcher. Now the logic is much simpler. Does this look good now?
Removed this check in endElement.
Removed endElement altogether.
Good catch. But endDocument is no longer needed.

all of --> all
Can there be null matchers?
There can be multiple source matchers and multiple target matchers? Or at most one of each?
